Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Scaling of Unsteady Locomotor Performance and Maneuverability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Whales, the largest animals, must be able to maneuver in their aquatic environment to capture prey, avoid predators, navigate complex environments, and compete for mates. The ability to maneuver (e.g., accelerate, turn quickly and tightly) generally decreases as mass increases, suggesting there is an upper size limit for maneuvering aquatic animals. This study will evaluate the size dependence of maneuverability of the largest animals in the ocean, rorqual whales, performing natural behaviors in the wild. Custom-designed removable sensors placed on the bodies of free-ranging whales will record their movement while aerial drones with specialized cameras will measure the size and shape of the whales and their appendages (i.e., flippers, flukes) at the surface of the water. By combining these data with mathematical modeling of hydrodynamic forces, different sized whale species can be compared to determine mechanical constraints imposed by size as a driving force in the ecology and evolution of the world?s largest predators. This project will include the training of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in interdisciplinary research that integrates engineering and physics with biology. Further, the results may provide insights into the biomimetic design of autonomous underwater vehicles with enhanced maneuvering performance.

Movement is a fundamental aspect of animal life. Quantifying the fine-scale movement of individuals has important consequences for understanding physiological, ecological, and evolutionary processes. Maneuvering capacity is also critically important as it governs an animal's ability to capture prey, avoid predators and obstacles, inhabit complex environments, and compete for mates. Investigations into how animals maneuver in aquatic environments remains poorly understood, particularly for large animals at the extreme of animal body mass. This proposal develops a bio-logging and remote sensing approach, with computational modeling, to analyze the kinematics and maneuverability of free-ranging rorqual whales (Balaenopteridae) ranging in body mass by an order of magnitude. Swimming performance (i.e., acceleration: change in swimming velocity; agility: rate of turning; maneuverability: turning radius) will decrease as body size increases across rorqual species and that these mechanical constraints imposed by morphology size will be evident as a driving force in the ecology and evolution of the world's largest predators. Custom engineered multi-sensor animal-borne tags and Fluid Lensing cameras attached to aerial drones will be used to analyze the kinematics and morphology of rorquals in the open ocean. This approach enables us to quantify the high-resolution kinematics of rorquals engaged in natural maneuvers while simultaneously quantifying the morphological dimensions of tagged animal, including control and propulsion surfaces. POR.DRECONTENT:
Whales, the largest animals, exhibit high performance locomotion at low energetic cost. Whales must be able to maneuver in their aquatic environment to capture prey, avoid predators, and navigate complex environments. Such maneuvers are predicted to suffer at larger body sizes, where the ability to accelerate and turn quickly generally decreases as mass increases in other animals, suggesting there is an upper size limit for maneuvering aquatic animals. However, the largest whales are regularly observed performing acrobatic maneuvers and demanding tasks such as completely leaving the water at high velocities. This study evaluated the size dependence of maneuverability of the largest animals in the ocean, rorqual whales, performing natural behaviors in the wild. Custom-designed removable sensors placed on the bodies of free-ranging whales recorded their movement while aerial drones with specialized cameras will measured the size and shape of the whales and their appendages (i.e., flippers, flukes) at the surface of the water. We combined these data with mathematical modeling of hydrodynamic forces to determine the mechanical constraints imposed by size as a driving force in the ecology and evolution of the world’s largest predators. 

At the largest scale, the blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived and has been previously described as a slow moving “gentle giant”. However, we revealed the detailed three-dimensional trajectories of whales such as the 360-degree barrel rolls that occur at high speeds in blue whales. We also showed that blue whales use their body flexibility to enhance maneuvering performance despite the physical limitations of a large body. Further, we characterized the full maneuverability portfolio of blue whales and other closely related species that varied in body mass by a factor of ten. We demonstrated that whales performed simple maneuvers (rolls, turns, and pitch changes) by using distinct combinations of control and power provided by the flippers and flukes, the high-aspect ratio appendages that resemble engineered wings. Whales use these wing-like structures to generate thrust and torque to maneuver along complex trajectories. Although most whales use flippers somewhat like aircraft, humpback whales are able to flap their flippers in a hydrodynamically active stroking pattern to enhance their maneuvering performance. This behavior is the first observation of a lift-generating flipper-stroke for propulsion in cetaceans and provides an additional function for the uniquely shaped humpback whale flipper.

The paired flukes on whale tails are oscillated to generate thrust to achieve speeds as great as 9 meters per second in order to fully breach the ocean surface. This maneuver likely represents maximum locomotor performance and the largest biomechanical event on earth. By analyzing tag data for breaches across scale, we revealed an underlying biomechanical explanation for the factors that limit breaching ability in large whales. Our study shows that breaching whales use a wide range of underwater trajectories, and that breaches with a high degree of emergence require speeds approaching the upper limits of locomotor performance. Although some species, like humpback whales breach frequently, larger species like blue whales and fin whales rarely breach. Our analyses suggest the breaching ability of large whales may be limited by the capacity of their muscles to deliver high bursts of power or sustain high-speed trajectories for extended durations. The confluence of muscle contractile properties, hydrodynamic limitations of lunate tail propulsion, and the higher speeds required for longer whales to emerge from the water likely imposes an upper limit to the body size and effectiveness of breaching whales. 

Broader Impacts of the project include both research and education initiatives. This project trained graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary research that integrated engineering and physics with biology. Our data sets may provide insights into the biomimetic design of autonomous underwater vehicles with enhanced maneuvering performance at high hydrodynamic efficiency. Broader impacts of the work also include increased understanding of whale biology, including several endangered species that are economically, ecologically, and culturally important.
